thread.title: How can Rutgers beat Big Ten elite?
thread.title_full: How can Rutgers beat Big Ten elite?

title: How can Rutgers beat Big Ten elite?
text:
How can Rutgers beat Big Ten elite? Stephen Edelson , @steveedelsonAPP 8:32 a.m. EDT October 10, 2015 Rutgers running back Josh Hicks and his backfield mates must be the key for the Scarlet Knights as they enter the toughest stretch in program history. (Photo: Associated Press) 3 CONNECT 5 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
PISCATAWAY – The return of star receiver Leonte Carroo and his big-play ability can only help the Rutgers offense. 
And head coach Kyle Flood will be back from his three-game suspension when he returns on the sideline next weekend at Indiana, which can’t hurt their gameday operation. 
But as the Scarlet Knights enter arguably the toughest stretch of games in program history, beginning with Saturday night’s Big Ten clash with No. 4 Michigan State at High Point Solutions Stadium, those won’t be the most important factors in determining whether or not they survive the gauntlet. 
Because their ability to consistently move the chains with their ground game, while sprinkling in those game-changing, electrifying runs to energize the sideline, will ultimately decide their fate. 
We can argue all day about whether Chris Laviano or Hayden Rettig should be their starting quarterback. The strength of the offense has to be its vaunted corps of running backs, touted as one of the best collections of talent in the nation. 
The blueprint is there. Shilique Calhoun planning B1G homecoming on Saturday 
Last Saturday against Michigan State, Purdue ran the ball 32 times for 165 yards, a hefty 5.2-yard average. Markell Jones ripped off a 68-yard run as part of a 157-yard, two-touchdown effort. 
Indiana ran the ball 55 times for 176 yards and three touchdowns against Ohio State last Saturday, with the top-ranked Buckeyes coming to Piscataway on Oct. 24. 
While neither Purdue nor Indiana were able to pull off upsets, they had chances to win in close games. And a moral victory against the Spartans and Buckeyes, in front of enthusiastic crowds in primetime, wouldn’t be the worst thing that could happen. 
What can’t happen is what transpired at Penn State last month, when Rutgers produced just 43 rushing yards on 32 carries, or 1.2 yards-per-attempt in a 28-3 loss.
